title: My Honest Take on the Pear Tallow Balm for Winter Skin
body:
Okay so my face feels like paper. Not even nice paper. Like that cheap, scratchy paper they put in those exam table things at the doctor’s office. You know the one. It’s January. It’s dark at 4 PM. The air is so dry it’s basically just dust. And my skin? It’s freaking out. It’s tight. It’s flaky in weird patches, like my forehead decided to become a geography project. My cheeks have this rough texture that makes putting on anything else feel like spreading glue on sandpaper. Winter skincare is a whole different beast. Dry winter skin isn’t just a thing, it’s a full-time job I didn’t apply for.

I was scrolling on my phone one night, my foot was totally asleep from sitting weird, and I kept seeing stuff about beef tallow skincare. Tallow balm. Like, beef fat. For your face. I mean, come on. My first thought was literally “that sounds kinda gross.” I pictured something in a greasy tin. But I was also desperate. I’d tried that fancy hyaluronic acid serum that costs as much as my electric bill. I’d tried the thick creams that just sat on top of my skin feeling like a weird mask. Nothing was getting through. My skin was still that dry, tight feeling. So I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I found this little Etsy shop and ordered their Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear. Because if I’m gonna put beef fat on my face, it might as well smell like something nice.

## Why I Even Tried Beef Tallow on My Face

Look, I’m not a skincare scientist. I’m a person whose skin hurts when it’s cold. But the thing that made me pause was reading that tallow, like from grass-fed cows, is actually really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum, or whatever. So the idea is it gets absorbed deep because your skin recognizes it. It’s not just sitting there pretending to work. It’s actually going in. That made a weird kind of sense to me, more sense than a list of 20 chemical names I can’t pronounce. This stuff is made in France, whipped up so it’s not just a block of fat. It’s supposed to be good for super dry spots, chapped lips, even people with sensitive skin or eczema. I don’t have eczema but my winter skin might as well be its cousin.

Anyway. It showed up in this simple little jar. I opened it and poked it. Texture was… different. Not what I expected. It’s solid but soft? Like if cold butter and whipped cream had a baby. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it touches your skin. Not greasy. Just… disappears. And the smell? Okay. It’s Pear. But not like a Jolly Rancher. Not like a candle. It’s just this light, fresh, kinda clean fruity smell. It’s there and then it’s pretty much gone. It’s nice. It’s not screaming at you. I was worried it would be overwhelming but it’s the opposite. It’s just a subtle sweetness that makes the whole “beef fat” concept way less weird.

## What This Pear Tallow Balm Actually Does

So my routine now is stupid simple. I wash my face. I pat it kinda damp. Then I take a tiny scoop of this tallow balm, like half the size of a pea, rub it between my fingers to warm it up, and just press it into my skin. Especially my cheeks and forehead. And around my eyes, because why not. The first time I did it, I just sat there waiting for the greasy feeling. It never came. It just… soaked in. My skin felt calm. Not shiny. Not sticky. Just normal. But hydrated. Like it finally drank some water after being in the desert.

The real test was the next morning. I woke up and my face didn’t feel tight. That alone was a miracle. Usually, I’d wake up and my skin would feel like it shrank three sizes overnight. But nope. It felt soft. Not “product” soft. Just… my skin soft. Like how it feels in the summer sometimes. I’ve been using it for a few weeks now, just at night. The flaky patches on my forehead are gone. Completely. The rough sandpaper texture on my cheeks? Smooth now. I even used it on my lips when they were chapped and it worked better than any waxy lip balm I’ve ever had. It just fixed them overnight.

Here’s a random observation: my cat usually hates the smell of my skincare stuff and runs away. He just sat on my lap while I had this on. He didn’t care. Maybe he thinks I smell like a nice steak now. I don’t know. Wait, where was I going with this. Right, the results.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of Winter

So it’s still January. It’s still brutally dry out. But my skin isn’t fighting me anymore. Using a tallow balm for winter just… works. It’s the only thing that’s consistently kept that dry, tight feeling away. I don’t look “dewy” or whatever. I just look like I have normal skin. Which, in this season, feels like a huge win. I’ve started using a tiny bit on my knuckles too, because they were cracking from washing my hands all the time. Worked there too. It’s just a solid, simple thing that does one job really well: it moisturizes deeply. It doesn’t promise to make me look 20 again. It just promises to stop my face from feeling like parchment. And it delivers.

I should probably order another jar soon. I’m maybe a third of the way through this one and I don’t want to run out. I even told my mom about it, because her hands get so dry in the winter. She was skeptical too. “Beef fat, really?” But then she tried mine and she was like “oh. Huh.” I think she’s going to get some.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, I think so. From what I get, it’s really similar to the oils our skin already makes, so it absorbs well and doesn’t just clog stuff up. It’s like giving your skin something it already knows how to use. My face seems to think it’s good.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And my skin can get fussy. It absorbs so fast it doesn’t feel like it’s sitting there blocking anything. It feels more like it’s feeding my skin, not smothering it. If you’re super oily maybe start with a tiny bit, but for dry winter skin, it’s been perfect.

**What does the Pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s light. It’s like a fresh, clean pear smell but not candy-sweet. It’s not strong. You smell it when you open the jar and for a second when you put it on, and then it fades. It just makes the whole experience pleasant instead of medicinal.

So yeah. That’s my experience. If your skin is throwing a fit this winter and nothing else is cutting through the dryness, this tallow balm might be worth a shot. I was super skeptical and now I’m just… a person with comfortable skin. Which is all I wanted. I got mine from that Etsy shop, the Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear. Anyway, my skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s it.
random_tangent: I should probably order another jar soon
